heading: The colour that won at the Golden Globes 2017 red carpet
text: From Emily Ratajkowski in Reem Acra to Natalie Portman in Prada, yellow took centre stage at the red carpet.

heading: Celebrity inspiration for every kind of New Year’s Eve party
text: Whether you’ve been planning your NYE getaway for a month now or are just going to wing it come December 31, there’s no escaping pressure of, “What should I wear?” They say how you spend New Year’s Eve is how you’ll spend the rest of the year; so you might as well do it in style. brings you some celebrity inspiration, no matter what kind of party you’re attending.

heading: 12 wardrobe challenges to take on through 2017
text: Before the cynicism sets in—let’s face it, it’s bound to—continue your winning streak of making resolves. This year, challenge yourself in the sartorial department with these simple tweaks.

heading: 10 of the coolest resort trends you need to own this season
text: The resort runways are inarguably the most colourful. Inspired by imaginary dreamy getaways, the prints are fresher, colours vivid and shapes easy to move in. Florals, tropical prints and beach-happy silhouettes are easy picks for the season. Braver souls can try ’60s kitsch, granny chic and dandy cuts. City friendly looks come by way of urban romance, androgyny and vintage romance. Here’s a quick recap of the coolest trends spotted on the resort 2017 runways to guide you through the season.

heading: We’ve planned your vacation wardrobe so you won’t have to
text: Gear up for your getaway with our top resort wear picks.

heading: Fashion predictions to look out for in 2017
text: What will 2017 entail? Judging by the year that just passed, one can never be too sure of what the future holds. Having said that, we are going out on a limb to place our bets on the following.

heading: The cool new ways Bollywood is styling the classic white shirt
text: Considering that the classic white shirt is the very definition of a wardrobe MVP today, it’s hard to imagine that it created quite the scandal when it made its first appearance back in 1793. Worn by queen Marie Antoinette under a muslin dress for a portrait, it was considered against royal etiquette, far from the status the shirt enjoys today. Over the years, the white shirt has witnessed a transformation—what was considered a symbol of wealth in the 19th century as those who didn’t work wore it, was given a (then) revolutionary androgynous spin by Coco Chanel in the ’20s. Celebrities such as Audrey Hepburn, Lauren Bacall and Katherine Hepburn to Julia Roberts and Gwyneth Paltrow, have done their bit to make it even more iconic. The one-piece wonder continues to intrigues the most current Bollywood set too. Want to take your white shirt from office to cocktail party? Let Sonam Kapoor lead the way—swap those pinstriped trousers for a formal silk maxi skirt and a statement necklace to boot. If it’s a sangeet you’re attending, you can team your white shirt with a lehenga just as easily. Her sister, Rhea Kapoor, shows us how to give the shirt serious cool girl cred. A crisp white with exaggerated shoulders and light stripes, worn with high-waist trousers is just what you need for Saturday night drinks with your girls. What works in this staple’s favour is that it serves as a blank canvas for your sartorial sensibilities, in tune with the occasion in question. For instance, you can wear it with patchwork denim shorts and combat boots like for a music festival or with a feminine midi skirt à la Soha Ali Khan to meet the boyfriend’s parents. If you’re looking to add to your ever-increasing collection of white shirts, turn to one in its new-age avatar—the high-low knotted version seen on Malaika Arora Khan or the deconstructed one worn by —are great options. Safe to say, the classic white shirt is anything but basic.

heading: Leggings are not pants, but they still need to be a part of your wardrobe
text: We can all admit to that time we swore not to step out of the house in those comfy, button-free, shockingly slimming leggings. The concepts of pants and leggings are not quite the same, clearly—the volume of literature on the topic proves this. But the odds weigh in the favour of ease and what’s the general harm, we ask? One of the most-cited arguments against leggings is the view of the back. The VPL, the second-skin nature of the garment and the true-to-form visual of someone’s posterior can be a little unsettling; honestly, do we need such clarity of your form? For the sake of comfort sans faux pas, we recommend a few safety measures. It’s best to pick one after the light test. Avoid the thin cotton variety of leggings—they are just thick tights. Pick solid colours with a high thread count and sound opacity to nix the VPL. And just because you can squeeze yourself in a highly stretchy pair of pants, don’t forget about the muffin top. The resort 2017 lines embraced the rise of athleisure in mainstream fashion. Stylist and designer Andrea Lieberman of clothing line A.L.C. presented her resort 2017 mixed with everyday gym wear—think a gorgeous chunky knit over your favourite Nike tights. At M Missoni, the approach to leggings was far more direct—if you work out, there’s nothing to hide and second skin was the statement you made with form fitting clothing. Cédric Charlier went safe with suede leggings and crop tops, but not without an oversized boyfriend blazer to cover the rear. An ardent supporter of the ‘pants are pants’ rule might be hesitant to step out of their comfort zone, into a more comfortable zone. Instead of regular spandex, try leather leggings—a bit more ‘occasion friendly’ than what you sweat in on the gym floor. Seasoned rule breakers, feel free to step out in your favourite pair of workout leggings. Just do your best to stay away from the neon prints that are more gym friendly than street. When in doubt, ask thy celebrity—take cue for your favourite stars on making runway trends more wearable. From the Kardashians to Sonam Kapoor, celebs have already given in to the comforts of stretchy pants. Go through our gallery for more ideas on how to work this tricky trend.
